messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 51 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Solving parametric systems of polynomial equations over the reals through Hermite matrices

Paper Abstract: Abstract We design a new algorithm for solving parametric systems of equations having finitely many complex solutions for generic values of the parameters. More precisely, let 𝒇=(f1,…,fm)⊂ℚ​[𝒚]​[𝒙]𝒇subscript𝑓1…subscript𝑓𝑚ℚdelimited-[]𝒚delimited-[]𝒙{\bm{f}}=(f_{1},\ldots,f_{m})\subset\mathbb{Q}[{\bm{y}}][{\bm{x}}] with 𝒚=(y1,…,yt)𝒚subscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑡{\bm{y}}=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{t}) and 𝒙=(x1,…,xn)𝒙subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛{\bm{x}}=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}), 𝒱⊂ℂt×ℂn𝒱superscriptℂ𝑡superscriptℂ𝑛{\mathcal{V}}\subset\mathbb{C}^{t}\times\mathbb{C}^{n} be the algebraic set defined by the simultaneous vanishing of the fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}’s and π𝜋\pi be the projection (𝒚,𝒙)→𝒚→𝒚𝒙𝒚({\bm{y}},{\bm{x}})\to{\bm{y}}. Under the assumptions that 𝒇𝒇{\bm{f}} admits finitely many complex solutions when specializing 𝒚𝒚{\bm{y}} to generic values and that the ideal generated by 𝒇𝒇{\bm{f}} is radical, we solve the following algorithmic problem. On input 𝒇𝒇{\bm{f}}, we compute semi-algebraic formulas defining open semi-algebraic sets 𝒮1,…,𝒮ℓsubscript𝒮1…subscript𝒮ℓ\mathcal{S}_{1},\ldots,\mathcal{S}_{\ell} in the parameters’ space ℝtsuperscriptℝ𝑡\mathbb{R}^{t} such that ∪i=1ℓ𝒮isuperscriptsubscript𝑖1ℓsubscript𝒮𝑖\cup_{i=1}^{\ell}\mathcal{S}_{i} is dense in ℝtsuperscriptℝ𝑡\mathbb{R}^{t} and, for 1≤i≤ℓ1𝑖ℓ1\leq i\leq\ell, the number of real points in 𝒱∩π−1​(η)𝒱superscript𝜋1𝜂{\mathcal{V}}\cap\pi^{-1}({\eta}) is invariant when η𝜂{\eta} ranges over 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}. This algorithm exploits special properties of some well chosen monomial bases in the quotient algebra ℚ​(𝒚)​[𝒙]/Iℚ𝒚delimited-[]𝒙𝐼\mathbb{Q}({\bm{y}})[{\bm{x}}]/I where I⊂ℚ​(𝒚)​[𝒙]𝐼ℚ𝒚delimited-[]𝒙I\subset\mathbb{Q}({\bm{y}})[{\bm{x}}] is the ideal generated by 𝒇𝒇{\bm{f}} in ℚ​(𝒚)​[𝒙]ℚ𝒚delimited-[]𝒙\mathbb{Q}({\bm{y}})[{\bm{x}}] as well as the specialization property of the so-called Hermite matrices which represent Hermite’s quadratic forms. This allows us to obtain “compact” representations of the semi-algebraic sets 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i} by means of semi-algebraic formulas encoding the signature of a given symmetric matrix. When 𝒇𝒇{\bm{f}} satisfies extra genericity assumptions (such as regularity), we use the theory of Gröbner bases to derive complexity bounds both on the number of arithmetic operations in ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} and the degree of the output polynomials. More precisely, letting d𝑑d be the maximal degrees of the fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}’s and 𝔇=n​(d−1)​dn𝔇𝑛𝑑1superscript𝑑𝑛\mathfrak{D}=n(d-1)d^{n}, we prove that, on a generic input 𝒇=(f1,…,fn)𝒇subscript𝑓1…subscript𝑓𝑛{\bm{f}}=(f_{1},\ldots,f_{n}), one can compute those semi-algebraic formulas using O​~​((t+𝔇t)​ 23​t​n2​t+1​d3​n​t+2​(n+t)+1)𝑂~absentbinomial𝑡𝔇𝑡superscript23𝑡superscript𝑛2𝑡1superscript𝑑3𝑛𝑡2𝑛𝑡1O\ {\widetilde{\leavevmode\nobreak\ }}\left(\binom{t+\mathfrak{D}}{t}\ 2^{3t}\ n^{2t+1}d^{3nt+2(n+t)+1}\right) arithmetic operations in ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} and that the polynomials involved in these formulas have degree bounded by 𝔇𝔇\mathfrak{D}. We report on practical experiments which illustrate the efficiency of this algorithm, both on generic parametric systems and parametric systems coming from applications since it allows us to solve systems which were out of reach on the current state-of-the-art.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 51 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 51"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A refined laser method and faster matrix multiplication",
        "Étude des systèmes algébriques surdéterminés. Applications aux codes correcteurs et à la cryptographie.",
        "On the complexity of the F5 Gröbner basis algorithm",
        "Algorithms in Real Algebraic Geometry (Algorithms and Computation in Mathematics)",
        "A theorem on refining division orders by the reverse lexicographic order",
        "Determinantal sets, singularities and application to optimal control in medical imagery",
        "The complexity of quantifier elimination and cylindrical algebraic decomposition",
        "Solving systems of nonlinear polynomial equations faster",
        "Quantifier elimination for real closed fields by cylindrical algebraic decomposition: a synopsis",
        "Using computer algebra tools to classify serial manipulators",
        "Thom’s first isotopy lemma: a semialgebraic version, with uniform bounds(real singularities and real algebraic geometry)",
        "Ideals, Varieties, and Algorithms: An Introduction to Computational Algebraic Geometry and Commutative Algebra, 3/e (Undergraduate Texts in Mathematics)",
        "Sharp estimates for triangular sets",
        "Real quantifier elimination is doubly exponential",
        "On the bit complexity of finding points in connected components of a smooth real hypersurface",
        "Polynomial systems solving by fast linear algebra",
        "A new efficient algorithm for computing Gröbner bases (F4)",
        "A new efficient algorithm for computing Gröbner bases without reduction to zero (F5)",
        "Classification of the perspective-three-point problem, discriminant variety and real solving polynomial systems of inequalities",
        "On the complexity of the generalized minrank problem",
        "FGb: A Library for Computing Gröbner Bases",
        "A package for solving parametric polynomial systems",
        "Signatures in algebra, topology and dynamics",
        "Algebraic solution of systems of polynomial equations using Gröebner bases",
        "When polynomial equation systems can be \"solved\" fast?",
        "A gröbner free alternative for polynomial system solving",
        "Semi-algebraic local-triviality in semi-algebraic mappings",
        "Smooth points on semi-algebraic sets",
        "Plane geometry and convexity of polynomial stability regions",
        "Sur le nombre des racines d’une équation algébrique comprises entre des limites données. extrait d’une lettre á m. borchardt.",
        "Uber eine elementare transformation eins in bezug auf jedes von zwei variablen-systemen linearen und homogenen ausdrucks.",
        "On the stability of gröbner bases under specializations",
        "Grundzüge einer arithmetischen theorie der algebraischen grössen.",
        "Self-entrainment of a population of coupled non-linear oscillators.",
        "Solving parametric polynomial systems",
        "Degrevlex gröbner bases of generic complete intersections.",
        "Generic sequences of polynomials.",
        "Counting real zeros in the multivariate case.",
        "Solving zero-dimensional systems through the rational univariate representation.",
        "Real alebraic geometry library, raglib (version 3.4)",
        "Polar varieties and computation of one point in each connected component of a smooth real algebraic set.",
        "A nearly optimal algorithm for deciding connectivity queries in smooth and bounded real algebraic sets.",
        "Bit complexity for multi-homogeneous polynomial system solving—application to polynomial minimization.",
        "Computing parametric geometric resolutions.",
        "Basic Algebraic Geometry 1: Varieties in Projective Space.",
        "A demonstration of the theorem that every homogeneous quadratic polynomial is reducible by real orthogonal substitution to the form of a sum of positive and negative squares.",
        "Regularisation of Gröbner basis computations for weighted and determinantal systems, and application to medical imagery.",
        "A complete algorithm for automated discovering of a class of inequality-type theorems.",
        "Real solution classification for parametric semi-algebraic systems.",
        "Equi-cevaline points on triangles.",
        "An open problem on metric invariants of tetrahedra."
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 51 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Solving parametric systems of polynomial equations over the reals through Hermite matrices, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
